references: Most importantly, all existing FL approaches shown in TableÂ 7 can use finetuning either to personalize shared global model(s) or as a complementary personalization strategy to further adapt their personalized models. Since our proposed FedL2P focus on better personalizing shared global model(s) by learning better a personalized policy which leverages the clientsâ€™ local data statistics relative to the given pretrain model(s), our approach is complementary to all existing FL solutions that learn shared model(s); we showed improvements over a few of these works in TableÂ 1.

references:
We evaluate our approach based on the conventional setup of personalized FL approachesÂ Chen etÂ al. (2022); Matsuda etÂ al. (2022b), where a global model, Î¸gsubscriptğœƒğ‘”\theta_{g}, is first learned federatedly using existing algorithms
and then personalized to the same set of clients via fine-tuning. To this end, given the CIFAR-10 dataset partitioned among a group of clients, we pretrained Î¸gsubscriptğœƒğ‘”\theta_{g} following best practices fromÂ Horvath etÂ al. (2021) using FedAvg and finetune it on the same set of clients. TableÂ 2 shows the personalized accuracy of the various fine-tuning baselines (SectionÂ 4.1.2) and FedL2P using e=5&15ğ‘’515e=5\&15 local epochs on groups of clients with varying label distribution, Piâ€‹(y)subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–ğ‘¦P_{i}(y); Î±=1000ğ›¼1000\alpha=1000 represents the IID case and Î±=1.0,0.5,0.1ğ›¼1.00.50.1\alpha=1.0,0.5,0.1 represents more heterogeneous case. As observed in many previous worksÂ Oh etÂ al. (2021); Jiang etÂ al. (2019), increasing label heterogeneity would result in a better initial global model at a expense of personalized performance. Our method instead retains the initial global performance and focuses on improving personalized performance.

references: We evaluate our method on Office-Caltech-10 and DomainNet datasets commonly used in domain generalization/adaptation, which exhibit both marginal and conditional feature shifts. Differing from the conventional FL setup, we adopted a pretrained model trained using ImageNetÂ

and attached a prediction head as our global model.
Similar to CIFAR-10-C experiments, we compare our method with the baselines in Table.Â
. Unlike CIFAR-10/10-C, Office-Caltech-10 and DomainNet consist of images from distinct domains and adapting to these domain result in a model sparsity of 0 as shown in Fig.Â
. Hence, a better personalization performance is achieved using the clientâ€™s own local BN statistics (
). Lastly, each clientâ€™s personalized model uses an extent of the pretrained natural image statistics as well as its own domain statistics, for both datasets.

We use the default parameters for spectral clustering from

to assign labels on the normalized Laplacian embedding. We then compute the
between the estimated clusters and the clusters partitioned by the different data domains as shown in Table.Â

.

As shown, for DomainNet, both BNNet and LRNet consistently preserve the cluster information found in their inputs,

references: TableÂ 7 shows the positioning of FedL2P against existing literature. Note that this list is by no means exhaustive but representative to highlight the position of our work. Most existing approaches obtained personalized models using a personalized policy and local data, often through a finetuning-based approach. This personalized policy can either 1)Â be fixed, e.g. hand-crafting hyperparameters, layers to freeze, selecting number of mixture components, number of clusters or 2)Â learned, e.g. learning a hypernetwork to generate weights or meta-nets to generate hyperparameters. These approaches are also grouped based on whether this personalized policy is dependent on the local data during inference, e.g. meta-nets require local client meta-data to generate hyperparameters.

Most importantly, all existing FL approaches shown in TableÂ 7 can use finetuning either to personalize shared global model(s) or as a complementary personalization strategy to further adapt their personalized models. Since our proposed FedL2P focus on better personalizing shared global model(s) by learning better a personalized policy which leverages the clientsâ€™ local data statistics relative to the given pretrain model(s), our approach is complementary to all existing FL solutions that learn shared model(s); we showed improvements over a few of these works in TableÂ 1.

We present the learned hyperparameters for the other client groups not shown in Fig.Â

(as an initial condition learner) is not a meaningful point of comparison because our problem is to fine-tune/personalize pre-trained models. Therefore, to compare with FOMAML, we focus on learning our FedL2P meta-nets with FOMAML style meta-gradients instead of IFT meta-gradients. In order to apply FOMAML to learning rate optimization, this also required extending FOMAML with the same trick as we did for our IFT approach as shown in Eq.Â
. However, FOMAML ignores the learning trajectory except the last step, which may result in performance degradation over longer horizons. We term this baseline FOMAML+. Table.Â
reports results on the multi-domain datasets as described in Section.Â
